Award.AwardTitle: Function and Regulation of Isoprene Synthesis in Leaves
Award.AbstractNarration: Isoprene is emitted from many plants, especially trees such as oaks and aspens. The amount emitted is very large and has significant effects on atmospheric chemistry. On the other hand, isoprene can serve as a chemical feedstock and is already being exploited commercially. To understand the function and regulation of isoprene emission from plants, experiments will be undertaken to test and determine how plants that emit isoprene are affected by this emission. Novel optical methods will be used to measure leakiness of photosynthetic membranes and determine how isoprene affects this leakiness. The effect of isoprene on other membrane functions, such as formation of lipid drops and possible cell death signals will also be measured. Experiments to test the regulation will focus on measuring enzyme activity with and without possible inhibitors and measuring changes in enzyme activities in relation to changes in isoprene emission rate. The results of the work will be useful for understanding isoprene emission, one of the most important chemical interactions between the biosphere and atmosphere. This information may aid decisions such as whether to alter what trees are planted and will aid in predicting when air pollution episodes are likely to be exacerbated by isoprene. The work may also be useful in engineering other organisms to make isoprene so that it can be used as a replacement for petroleum. This research will involve many students including undergraduates recruited to a summer program designed to increase participation in science by members of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This four-year grant funded a variety of projects related to understanding isoprene emission from plants. Isoprene is the major hydrocarbon entering the atmosphere and it comes from plants, mostly trees such as oaks and aspen. In this project the internal controls over the rate of isoprene emission were investigated. Fundamentally new insights were obtained about how the rate of isoprene emission is controlled by plants. A strong feedback mechanism was identified that had not been predicted. This mechanism appears to be a general effect and so is relevant to nearly all forms of life, from bacteria to humans. The results are important not only for understanding and predicting isoprene emission but also for understanding reactions in parasites such as malaria so that new antimalarial drugs might be developed. The results might also help the biotech industry in finding commercially viable methods of making isoprene (a precursor to rubber) and other chemicals used in the flavors and fragrance industry.

            A second major investigation showed that the last step in the synthesis of isoprene is catalyzed by an enzyme that shows restricted genetic variability. The results indicate that there are additional genes related to isoprene production to be discovered. This discovery allows the prediction that isoprene emission in oaks and aspen probably arose 100 million years ago. These studies also provide the knowledge needed to engineer better enzymes for use in industry. As part of this project two genes were discovered in soy bean that appear to have been permanently turned off showing that the progenitors of modern soybeans had the capacity to make isoprene but this capacity has been lost in today’s modern varieties.

            A third part of the study looked at why plants make isoprene. Isoprene caused membrane swelling, similar to some volatile anesthetics. This effect may explain how isoprene can protect leaves against high temperatures they can experience on sunny days. The alternative explanation, that isoprene is an antioxidant like vitamins A, C, or E, was not supported by the data. This helps explain why some plants make isoprene while others do not.

            This work made significant progress in the fundamental understanding of this very important process and also provided important new knowledge for the biotechnology industry. While carrying out this research nine undergraduate students participated in the research, four of whom were selected in a program designed to increase women and underrepresented groups in science.

            The results were published in 14 original research papers, one review paper, and another review paper is currently under consideration for publication. Two additional publications are expected to come in part from the work carried out in this project.
